reviewText: When the NBC Mystery Movie Format kicked in...SNOOP SISTERS was one of the earlier (and later discarded) ideas for a rotating series.  Pairing up Helen Hayes and Mildred Natwick was an interesting idea.While the pilot with Art Carney...who played their chauffer and protector, Barney...was very good....the 4 follow-up episodes couldn't measure up.  It seemed as if the ladies were constantly going backwards and forwards throughout each trying to find motives for murder.  This was noticeable when I watched the first 2 regular episodes back-to-back. When I started tapping my feet or hitting the pause button to pour a 2nd glass of wine or grab a frozen Milky Way...I knew I was getting bored.  Many of the excellent guest stars couldn't save the stagnant storylines. [MURDER SHE WROTE used several of the same ones much better].Going back to the pilot, I never realized how beautiful Paulette Goddard was.  This turned out to be her final role before her death.  What a lovely lady.  Too bad she was the victim before the first 20 minutes were over! :(

reviewText: Every now and again, when in the mood for classy actors on television, I would watch those two Broadway Stars, Helen Hayes and Mildred Natwick, needing only a mite of their talents, prance neatly through the few episodes of this series. The pilot is the best offering, featuring as it does the highly estimable, Art Carney, as their chauffeur and elder-sitter. His replacement in the other four episodes is adequate- but just not Art Carney. Guest stars, as was true in Murder she Wrote, usually included veteran stars and character actors. The Sisters, a joy to see in action, solve mysteries that just happen to occur about them. Plots are sound, over-all acting quality high, production values about what one expects from the period on modern equipment. For those who enjoy minimal violence, subdued humor, essentially non-complex mystery, and, leave-them-in-a good-mood television, I highly recommend watching.But Not At These Prices. At more than 8 bucks a show (currently listed Amazon price)I think the over-payment will mar your enjoyment. Just not worth those prices.

reviewText: Yes, the price is twice what it should be for five episodes.  Nevertheless,I'm pleased that someone is interested in packaging these little rememberedprograms.When this series debuted I  was quite familiar with the work of the legendaryHelen Hayes, but had just a vague awareness of Mildred Natwick.  For thosewho need their memory jogged, Miss Natwick was Oscar nominated for "Barefootin the Park", and years earlier was a major highlight in Danny Kaye's classic"The Court Jester", as well as Hitchcock's "The Trouble With Harry".  But it was"The Snoop Sisters" that at last made me a fan of this marvelous scene-stealingactress.  For her role it this series she won a well deserved Emmy Award.A previous reviewer mentioned that the programs seem a bit slow.  That's true,especially when one is used to hour mysteries, but keep in mind that "The Snoop Sisters"was part of the rotating Mystery Movie series and thus are 30 minutes longer than weare used to.  That extra length, plus the professional stature of Hayes and Natwick,attracted an unusual number of top flight guest stars (the great Geraldine Page, for instance).My favorite episode is "Black Day for a Bluebeard" (Vincent Price, Tammy Grimes,Roddy McDowall, Mort Sahl, William Devane) in which there is a hilarious battle ofwits between Price and Natwick, both at the top of their game.

reviewText: Ernesta and Gwendolyn Snoop are sisters extraordinaire. They live together in NYC after Gwendolyn's husband died. They are elderly, smart, classy, feisty and possessed of a curiosity that gets them constantly into trouble. In particular, they just cannot leave a mystery alone; unable to suppress their powers of observation and deductive reasoning. Should I mention their ability to fib their way out of most situations? You'll have to watch the show to see Gwendolyn say, with a straight face, "Exterminating is my hobby. I read palms professionally."We first meet the sisters when Ernesta, casual in her striped pajamas, clutches a letter opener as she intones, "I'll kill you. If you come any closer, I'll kill you." She plunges the letter opener into the desktop - at which sits Gwendolyn in her pink peignoir, writing down every word Ernesta says.Ernesta is a famed mystery writer, working on her new book. She continues her narrative, "Bewilderment replaced his rage and fear. Suddenly, she felt the familiar pity for those faded blue eyes..."Gwendolyn inturrupts, "I think, Dear, Howard's eyes were brown in the last chapter."And there, in a nutshell, is their relationship. They work together well, support each other and gently correct each other. They're so close they can finish each others' sentences. Actually, often they don't need to complete the sentence to know what the other is thinking. The dears are dearly loved by their nephew, Police Lieutenant Steven Ostrowski. Given their age, and living alone in the city, he has hired Barney to be their chauffeur and general factotum.Poor Barney. The sisters are always talking him into doing things he knows he oughtn't. In the episode, "Corpse and Robbers", the three of them actually end up in the pokey for a short time. The Lieutenant is furious: "OK Barney. How do you explain this?"Barney: "Poorly"Lt: "Your job is what?"Barney: "Take care of the ladies. See that they don't get into trouble."Lt: "Which means?"Barney: "You gotta put more men on the job."Ernesta: "Steven, don't be harsh with Barney."Gwendolyn: "It wasn't his fault."Ernesta: "We overpowered him."There is a lot of delightful humor in this series, situational, dialogue, and character interactions, and including slapstick. Helen Hayes (plays Ernesta) and Mildred Natwick (Gwendolyn) are old pros. and their interactions are seamless. Hayes has a smile that could light up a football stadium, and is especially adorable when attempting to look innocent. I remember Natwick from one of my favorite classic movies, "The Court Jester", with Danny Kaye. She is Griselda, "The pellet with the poison's in the flagon with the dragon! The vessel with the pestle has the brew that is true!"Comparing this to other series, this has the silly comedy and characters that remind me of "Get Smart". It has the nice plotting and deductive reasoning that remind me of "Murder She Wrote". It has the character chemistry and charm that remind me of "Rockford Files". Great Guest Stars: Paulette Goddard (her very last screen appearance), Art Carney (plays Barney in the pilot, only), Victor Buono, Geraldine Page, Walter Pidgeon, Steve Allen, Joan Blondell, George Maharis, Alice Cooper(!), Vincent Price, William DeVane and Roddy McDowall.The pilot originally aired on ABC in December 1972. There followed only four 90-minute episodes, which appeared in rotation on NBC's "Wednesday Mystery Movie", along with 3 other shows, including "Banacek". It is a shame it did not find a wider audience, because Hayes and Natwick are a real treat to watch in action.
summary: Thoroughly Enjoyable Mystery Series With a Couple of Old Pros in the Leads!

reviewText: I second the reviewer's question about the make of car. It's so wonderful to see these great gals driving around in that great old car!In fact, I think this whole show is just fabulous! It's been wonderful for me to return to the world of my high school years -- when people actually behaved in ways befitting their age; when there was a certain respect between people (and with the police) that was displayed by the media. Give me these sweet old mysteries any day over the psychotic serial killers, bad cops and all the blood and gore of today.The nostalgia is worth the price!

reviewText: Episode 1 - A woman, about to publish a tell-all book, is murdered.2 - The recently deceased founder of a struggling toy factory telephones Ernesta - is he dead?3 - A basketball player is on edge, no one has an antacid to give him except Gwendolyn, after taking it, he passes out: he barely survives - it seems he has been poisoned.4 - Unbeknownst to Ernesta, a man - she met on the plane - put a pentagram etched amulet in her bag, and now he is dead; a coven wants the amulet back.  (Perhaps watching this episode put a hex on disc 3, because . . . .)Disc problem:  Episode 4 and 5 are on disc 3.  On the initial play of Episode 4 there was a faint humming noise coming from the blu-ray player.  Stopped the player for the night, restarted in the morning to watch 5.  The player refused to play and made a buzzing noise.  Reset the player, restarted.  It was still noisy but the menu came up, selected 5: the player quit.  Tried several times, same result.  Removed the disc, examined it: no visible flaws.  Inserted it in the backup DVD player; the player began buzzing loudly, very loudly.  The menu did come up though, selected 5, and it began playing, however I stopped it: the player was just making too much racket.Slow delivery:  On my order, time to receive after the order was made:  25 days.Note:  At the time of this submission, Amazon's Product Details lists the studio for this product as Millennium Media Services, however, the box credits Visual Entertainment Inc. (VEI) under license from NBC Universal, Inc.Picture (DVD): 3 to 4.  Sets with a bad disc warrant an overall rating of 1.
summary: So-so Shows, Bad Disc 3, Slow Delivery

reviewText: Helen Hayes, Myrna Loy, Mildred Natwick and Silvia Sidney starred in a Movie of the Week called Do Not Fold Spindle or Mutilate.NBC had a hit with their Sunday NBC Mystery Movie anthology, they decided to expand it to Wednesday night.  The original rotating schedule included Banacek, Madigan, Faraday and Company and Cool Million.  Faraday and Cool Million were quickly cancelled.  The producers remembered the aforementioned special and decided to adapt the MOW.Instead of four stars two were kept.  Hayes was fresh off her deserved Oscar win for Airport and her charm is still was used to the hilt.  Natwick was perfect as her sister.Ernesta and Gwendolyn Snoop write mystery novels but they get their inspiration from real cases they solve.  While the stories were very pedestrian, the stars made it enjoyable.  But they could not save it from cancellation after five episodes.The following are the five episodes:The Female InstinctCorpse and RobbersFear is a Free ThrowThe Devil Made Me Do ItBlack Day for BluebeardNote: Mildred Natwick won an Emmy for Best Actress in a Limited Series beating her costar, Helen Hayes
summary: Do Not Fold Spindle or Mutilate

reviewText: Ms Natwick and Ms Hayes shine in this series of sisters of means who are sleuths. Light, frothy, but totally entertaining they were forerunners of female detectives on a series called Mystery Night that revolved thru several stars series. I was amazed at their ability to charge about at 70 and look GREAT! These ladies have great chemistry and the plots were best at the beginning but by the end you are so happy to watch the banter and them being driven about in an elegant antique car...Art Carney was in the pilot but not the series..our loss.this isn't Bruce Willis action but think you will enjoy it! I did!

reviewText: People complain about the price but for some things I will pay gladly and the Snoop Sisters on DVD are one of those RARE Treasures that I will pay the price and LIKE IT!  Growing up I remember the Snoop Sisters all too well.  I almost paid more than the current price for ONE  very grainy DVD copy of a 16mm film Snoop Sister episode, I was outbid in the final seconds and devastated at my loss.  I would routinely check Amazon.com for the Snoop Sisters on DVD because; Amazon tends to get DVD's of TV Shows I love from my youth.  I figure the company creating the Snoop Sister DVD knows this set has limited appeal which is reflected in its higher price.  You know whatever the reason for the higher price for the Snoop Sisters, I'll pay to have the Snoop Sisters on DVD because; I so totally loved them growing up.  I loved the Snoop Sisters and their WILD WILD HATS.  I loved their old FORD Lincoln  and the fact they really could not drive yet never had an accident while cause all kinds of roadway havoc.  I am autistic so I used to rename shows according to what I liked most about them.  I used to call the Snoop Sisters, "My Dear Ladies" because they were so sweet and nice.  I felt the Snoop Sisters were fun.  As an autistic kid I never had real friends so I would make friends with people on TV.  I used to imagine what it would be like to hang out with the Snoop Sisters as my friends.  The Snoop Sisters were so much fun for me growing up.  Helen Hayes was so sweet I used to cry because; I enjoyed watching her enjoy being herself no matter who she upset and no matter what happened in the world around her.  I enjoyed the Snoop Sisters because; they were old and odd and no one expected them to still be vital enough to solve murders  but they were still awesome.  I always enjoyed stories about STRONG VITAL LADIES and these two old dears were the strongest ladies I remember on TV growing up.  At $31.00 the Snoop Sisters DVD's are still higher in price than expected but I brought my copy of the Snoop Sisters while filled with joy and gusto because; they were friends who were one of the few bright spots from my troubled autistic youth.  These dear ladies the Snoop Sisters I always remembered and wanted on DVD.  This Snoop Sister set was the answer to my prayers and I could give a hoot that the set cost $31.00.  The DVD quality was pretty good.  Sometimes the sound and lip synch were off.  The Snoop Sister DVD picture quality was great for an early 1970's era recording capture.  I love the musical score for the Snoop Sisters.  Sometimes I play the Snoop Sisters intro loop just to hear the Snoop Sister theme music.  Now that I am 53 years old I pray I have grown old, odd and happy like the dear Snoop Sisters.  After all these years it is nice to know the Snoop Sisters STILL ROCK!  I was happy to buy the Snoop Sisters at this price.I have one last DVD set I'd like to see from the 1970's a show called LUCAN about a boy raised till age 10 by Wolves in the wilds of Minnesota.  The Lucan series like the Snoop Sisters was a short lived series on the ABC Network.  The entire Lucan series had just twelve episodes including its movie length pilot.  I'd gladly pay $1000.00 for a great copy of the Lucan episode pilot and its complete eleven one hour episodes.  I love that the Snoop Sisters made it to DVD and it gives me hope that someday I will see Lucan and its twelve episodes released on DVD..  Thanks to Amazon.com I have DVD sets of the most treasured shows from my autistic youth.  For me growing up autistic in the 1960's, 1970's and 1980's TV show characters were the closest things I had to friends.  In my autistic youth, I looked forward to visits with my TV friends each week.  Having the ability to visit my TV friends via DVD now that I am an old successful autistic man is priceless to me.  I must say, Thank You AMAZON.COM for giving me the awesome opportunity to buy the Snoop Sisters and other awesome Old series on DVD's which together comprise the best memories of my otherwise painful autistic youth!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Not a perfect series, but always entertaining. I have always had fond memories of this show, particularly because of Millie Natwick, who was good in anything she did. So glad to see this finally released on DVD. I cannot understand why people are complaining about the price. The average cost of a film on DVD is anywhere from $10 to $20 dollars. Here you have FIVE tv films for what is now less than $50. The series has a limited audience to sell to, and that is what dictates the price. The more they can sell, the lower they are able to make the prices. That is how this business works.I bought mine, paid full price and am totally satisfied and enjoying every moment of nostalgia.

reviewText: I just received my copy of The Snoop Sisters today and what they claim to be the pilot doesn't appear to be.  It is the only episode on Disc 1, but where are Myrna Loy and Sylvia Sidney who were in the original movie (Do Not Fold, Spindle or Mutilate)?  I knew they weren't in the series when it first aired so I was a little surprised when viewing what I consider the first episode and not the original pilot.The claimed pilot doesn't even have the correct title and shows as an episode of The Snoop Sisters.  What's the deal with this?  The packaging claims the pilot is also known as "Female Instinct."  Are they claiming the first episode to be the pilot?  For so few episodes for the "complete series," they could have included the original movie unless it disintegrated years ago.I guess we're lucky to get anything at all, but for the price charged they could have included the original TV movie.  I remember this series and the original TV movie, and this is not the original pilot as claimed.  I think whoever manufacturered these discs never saw the original TV movie.Even though a little disappointing, I still give it five stars because it's a good show and I've been wanting this series since video recorders came out.  I've only viewed the first episode and so far the picture quality is clear, the colors a lot sharper than I expected, and the sound quality excellent.
Title: N/A
